Problem:
Consider a linear system where the temperature distribution \\(T(x,t)\\) along a rod evolves according to the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial T}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 T}{\\partial x^2}\\) where k is the thermal diffusivity. We analyze the effect of an intervention defined by a change in boundary conditions from \\(T(0, t) = T_0\\) (a constant temperature) to an impulse response \\(T(0, t) = T_0 + \\delta(t)\\) at a specific time.

If the boundary condition at \\(x=0\\) remains constant at \\(T_0\\) without any intervention, will the temperature distribution \\(T(L, t)\\) at the other end of the rod \\(x=L\\) be solely influenced by the initial condition \\(T(x,0)\\)?
Explanation: In the absence of any intervention, the temperature distribution at any point, including the end of the rod, is entirely determined by the heat equation and the initial/boundary conditions. No additional factors influence the evolution.
